post.subject: Internal Model Principle
post.message:
In the first few slides , design of controller for unbounded r(n) and v(n) are explained. The following questions are related to this topic.

1.Generally control system design is targeted for closed loop BIBO stability with internal stability (no cancellation unstable poles).  Why do we require bounded output for an unbounded input or disturbance?

2.Will this approach affect the tracking performance of the control system (step and ramp inputs are common – and are not bounded)? Could you please explain a little more detailed?

3.The controller designed with this theory is applicable for a particular type of functions (r(n) and v(n)) only.  Is it always possible to predict the nature of input (r(n)) and v(n)?. 

4. Suppose that αr and   αv  different  and this situation results in αv   in the  numerator of the closed loop transfer function and makes zeros outside unit cirlce. What are the effect of these zeros  on the closed loop output response y(n) to a tracking command  - r(n)?

5.Gc(z) in the given form results in a unstable(stand alone) controller and makes the loop transfer function unstable even if the open loop plant is stable.  This can create issues if there is physical break in the feedback signal(sensor failure , wire cut etc) .

6. Is this just a theoretical method of synthesizing controller? Can it be used for controlling practical systems?

(Edited by RAHUL PRAKASH - original submission Saturday, 2 February 2013, 10:49 PM)

post.subject: Internal stability
post.message:
sir,

i have an unstable plant transfer function lets say G(z) as z/(z-1.5). this plant is closed with Gc =1 to make it stable. r is set point, e is error = r-y, where y is output of the plant. by solving this we get y/r = G/(1+G)= z/(2*z-1.5). this gives me bounded output for bounded input. i also have e/r = 1/(1+G)= (z-1.5)/(2*z-1.5)= Gm(z) (lets say), this is stable too. so it fulfills internal stability criterion.

now if I say, r is input and e is internal variable to my closed loop system and y is output of the closed loop system. my system can be represented as open loop system with r as input to Gm(z) cascaded with G(z) and e as output of Gm(z) and input to G(z), y as final output to G(z). this seems to me as same system with all internal variables stable. but curiously, we have unstable pole  and zero cancelation between Gm(z) and G(z) here.

i also observed that this similarity evaporates if i add some noise at e (which is at input to my plant G(z)) in both these equivalent models. the original feedback model is still stable where as output of my open loop equivalent (as mentioned above) will be unstable.

 is it right, sir? please comment.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message:
1.  We would want the difference between the reference signal and the actual output to be small, even for an unbounded reference signal.  The reference signal could be a step or ramp, etc.

2.  No, it will not affect.

3.  If v(n) and r(n) are bounded signals, we need not know the exact nature.  But if it is an unbounded signal, we need to know it exactly.

4. A zero outside the unit circle gives rise to a nonminimum phase response.  This results in reduced performance.

5.  Yes, it is a terrible thing to use an unstable controller with an open loop stable plant, even if the closed loop system is stable.  What you have suggested is worse - you say that the closed loop system is unstable - it is not at all acceptable.  Why would you want to destabilise a stable system?

6.  We will use these theories to design controllers for practical systems.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: What you are saying is equivalent to $$\dfrac 1{1+G}\times G$$.  In this case, the unstable roots are identical - they come from the same G.  This cancellation is perfectly ok.

post.subject: Re: Delay modeling
post.message: Most of the real time systems have a some responce time that creates the time lag between input and output. Is there a way or method to design control which can react with realtime responces while the system delay is significant?

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: Inverted pendulum is an example.  It will fall down if no control is applied.  A bicycle is an unstable system.  If it is not driven, it will fall.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: The notion of stability that we use is in the sense of bounded input, bounded output.  With respect to tracking and disturbance rejection, we allow the exogeneous signals, i.e., v(n) and r(n) to be unbounded, so long as we know the exact nature.

post.subject: Re: Delay modeling
post.message:
Your question is not clear. 

Normally, the desired response is known to the person who operates it, we could call them the domain specialist or expert.  If they want to change the desired response with time, say, depending on plant conditions, it is very much possible.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: What do you mean by bounding the unbounded signals?  By this, do you mean the stabilisation of unbounded "systems"?

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: Yes.  We need the concepts of poles and zeros of MIMO systems, defined by matrices of transfer functions.  Smith McMillan form brings out the pole zero structure of MIMO systems.  A good reference on this topic is Thomas Kailath, Linear Systems.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: If these common terms have zeros inside the unit circle, there is no problem.  If these common terms are outside the unit circle, then it is forbidden.  Of course, we do talk about the cancellation of terms of the form $$(z-1)^n$$.  Here, we assume that we know these terms "exactly".  This topic is explained in the book.  We don't normally work with signals whose poles lie "outside" i.e., z>1, the unit circle.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: Your question is not clear.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: It is possible to make the digital controller almost identical to the analog controller through very high sampling rate.  At the same time, it is possible to design the digital controller quite different from its analog version by improper approximation.  In this case, we can certainly destabilise the system under focus.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message:
I guess that you are talking about slide 17.  What you are talking about is a 1x2 matrix and not a product.  As a result, the simplification of the form you have in mind is not at all possible.

You should compare the results of slide 17 with that of slide 13.  The $$-2$$ term, which creates all difficulties, is missing in slide 13.  This is the missing mode.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: I multiiplied the two transfer functions and cancelled the common factor.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: Although the controller by itself may be unstable, its output, namely u, need not be unstable.  You have to look at the closed loop transfer function between the reference signal r and the controller output u.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: What I mean is that if V is unbounded, we should know it "exactly".  If V is bounded, we need not know its exact nature.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: The nonminimum phase results in performance deterioration.  We may not be able to eliminate this effect.  This topic is discussed in detail in Chapter 9 of the book.  We will soon get to it in the class also.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: If B already has the factor $$\alpha$$, we need not include it in the controller $$G_c$$.

post.subject: Re: Internal model, stability questions
post.message: If we allow unstable pole-zero cancellation, some loop signals can grow unbounded, even if the output is perfectly bounded.  These unbounded signals can exceed the allowable limits and hence can result in a disaster.
